message.content:
<<<api>>>: Iterator.next
<<<code>>>: 
Map<String, Integer> map = new LinkedHashMap<>();
for (String s : list) {
    if (!map.containsKey(s)) {
        map.put(s, 1);
    } else {
        map.put(s, map.get(s) + 1);
    }
}

List<String> result = new ArrayList<>();
for (Map.Entry<String, Integer> entry : map.entrySet()) {
    for (int i = 0; i < entry.getValue(); i++) {
        result.add(entry.getKey());
    }
}
<<<explanation>>>: This code first creates a LinkedHashMap to store each unique string and its count. It then iterates over the list of strings, adding each string to the map and incrementing its count if it already exists. Finally, it creates a new list and populates it with the strings from the map, repeating each string according to its count. The use of LinkedHashMap ensures that the strings are ordered by their first appearance.
